question: Question_06_(c)
statement:
Consider the
function\begin{align*}f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.\end{align*}

\textbf{(c)} How many solutions are there to the equation
$\displaystyle f'(x)=0$? Justify your answer.
sols:
Recall that

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.$

From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)}, we know that $e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}\neq 0$. That implies that
$\displaystyle f'(x) = 0$ when $3x^2 + 4x + 1=0$. Factoring, we get
$(3x+1)(x+1)=0$, which means $x=-\frac{1}{3},-1$. That means there are
two solutions for when $\displaystyle f'(x)=0$.
hints:
The derivative was computed in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_06_(b)}{part
(b)}:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.\end{align*}

Now set the derivative and solve. This can be done either by factoring
or using the quadratic formula.
